DOC.HEAD: American Civilian Killed in Panama
Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Her husband ...' with relative saying husband was a civilian.
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An American schoolteacher who lived most of her life in Panama was killed by stray machine-gun fire from Panamanian forces during the early hours of the U.S. invasion, the State Department said today. Candy Helin, a 43-year-old whose husband is a former Dixon resident, was the only U.S. civilian reported killed in the attack begun early Wednesday. Mrs. Helin was a teacher of gifted students at a U.S. government school and is the daughter of a former Army port commander, family members said. Her husband, Steve Helin, 45, is a civilian financial analyst for the Panamerica Commission, an organization that oversees operation of the Panama Canal, his sister said. The former U.S. soldier has lived in Panama since 1962, when he joined the Army, according to his family. Douglas Rose, a spokesman for the State Department's Panama Task Force, said today that Mrs. Helin was killed by stray fire from the Panamanian Defense Forces. He said he had no additional details of her death. Helin's sister Jane Sheaffer of Dixon said Helin told her that his wife was killed in an ambush near the Albrook Air Force Base as the couple drove home on a dark road early Wednesday from dinner at a friend's. ``Obviously, he's really distraught _ distraught, angry and everything else, I suppose,'' Dean Sheaffer, Sheaffer's husband, said of Helin. ``It just doesn't seem real. She was murdered by the Panamanian government.'' Mrs. Helin was told recently her teaching position was being eliminated next year, but Mrs. Sheaffer said she did not know if that meant the couple had planned on returning to the United States. The couple have two children, Stephanie, 16, and Tracey, 20, family members said. Mrs. Sheaffer said her brother told her he did not know of the impending danger. Mrs. Scheaffer said a memo warning U.S. civilians to restrict their movements came after Helin had left work for the day on Tuesday.
